Another huge change thatâ€™s long overdue is the resolution and full screen viewing of photos. Come on already. The app is about sharing photos and we are still stuck with crappy cropped, low resolution photos that you canâ€™t see in full screen. Stop trying to make Instagram what it isnâ€™t with paying more attention to reels and get with what people want it for. Or sit back and watch other apps take over your space.

I add on to my review the number of restrictions Instagram automatically applies to peoples accounts. If you like and follow to many peoples pages (the entire point of Instagram) you get restrictions. If you try to manage your own account and unfollow or block to many people you get restricted. So whilst they make money from your creative content they restrict how you even manage it.

review:
Hi, I have non epileptic seizures (seizures that mimic epileptic seizures without sending electrical currents through the brain and instead is caused by something functional in the brain). Triggers for these seizures can include âœ¨strobe lightsâœ¨. Lately I have been coming across more and more videos that include strobe lights without the use of flash warnings and I usually comment to politely ask to add a warning however in some cases comments will be disabled or the creator with refuse to put a warning. I know that this isnâ€™t Instagrams fault but I have some ideas to help reduce the risk of seizures from videos containing strobe. 

I feel as if Instagram should add a feature to report videos containing flash to hide the video from photosensitive viewers much like the warnings used for graphic material. This can help protect ourselves from future seizures and flair ups. I know that some people think this might be a dumb request â€œthere arenâ€™t warnings in the real worldâ€ â€œtoughen up and get over itâ€ but the thing is that this IS the real world, we canâ€™t get over it because thatâ€™s just our life. For some people no flash warnings can be a matter between life or death. Youâ€™re playing with peoples lives here. People with seizures have gone through so much trauma, experiencing seizures are terrifying no matter how many you may get. 

Please consider this feature, Iâ€™ve had enough of this, and I am so tired. This is so important to us
title: Important request

review:
My biggest issue with Instagram lately is their application of community guidelines. They seem very inconsistent and biased- strictly following the guidelines with some content but not other similar content, especially when it comes to â€œpoliticalâ€ content... this can greatly affect what content you are allowed to see, comment on, post and share. The â€œfact checkâ€ feature also seems to be bias on particular things.

Reporting content and comments that are not appropriate, especially things regarding bullying and discrimination, or fake/scam accounts pretending to be other people, seems to do very little most of the time, and nothing is usually done about the post/comment you report- only suggesting you block the person you have reported, which doesnâ€™t always fix the issue. The process for reporting things like people stealing your content (copyright infringement) and/or invading your privacy, while generally more effective and successful than the conventional way of reporting things, is also much more difficult- itâ€™s hard to find where and how to send reports directly this way, and is more time consuming. 

The live streams always seem to be glitchy and troublesome, both for the host of the lives and the viewers. Editing reels and stories can also be a pain, with additional features not always loading, things being out of time after uploading, sound playing but the video being frozen, or the app crashing all together and randomly shutting down.

review:
I have always loved the idea of Instagram. I think the concept, what they have done in the social media sphere is amazing but I think there are ways we could make social media â€œhealthierâ€. It can be so hard for some people to have social media and not get sucked into a never ending rabbit hole. The results can be that people end up not living their life because hours and hours are spent scrolling, addicted to their phone. I understand social media is a large part of how a lot of people make their income but for many, it is a way to keep in touch with friends and search up new friends, be artistic, post life updates, message and so on. 

I would love to see a function on Instagram in the settings that allows the user (or even parents of kids) to disable the discovery page function. I think it would prevent the endless scrolling you can get sucked into. It would still allow you to search for accounts and friends but youâ€™re not exposed to everything and everyone the algorithm sends your way. review: I am an avid instagram user and love the app. There are a few simple changes though which would vastly improve the UX for visual collectors. Previously this was enabled for and it was so much better than the new meta version. 2) As a user who saves posts to multiple collections, I would love if Instagram could please change the save functionality to enable us to save the specific slide in a post as the cover slide in our saved collections as often the slides in a post have no correlation and the other slides are not relevant which muddles our saved collections. E.g. someone may have a dump of photos in a post and one has an outfit picture; another of flowers; family; kitchen etc and if the front is the family then it often has no correlation to a saved collection on â€œoutfitsâ€ or â€œinterior design - living spacesâ€.

review:
Instagram is a great platform to share photos and short videos and view content from other users that have different passions and interests. The explore functions work well and the tailored algorithm will ensure that posts you see have some relevance to your personal interests.

However, the comment function on Instagram is one of the worst Iâ€™ve experienced. There are very view options for formatting a comment and you cannot link anything. Iâ€™d you come across a comment chain that is quite long, you can only view 3 comments at a time, so accessing the earliest comments in the chain can be difficult. If you want to see replies to a comment you have made, all of the previous comments will be made inaccessible, and if you want to see previous comments when you have replied, all later responses will be inaccessible. There is also a chance when touching the screen while commenting for it to suddenly close the typing window, losing all progress. 

The comment system could really use some changes to reduce the frustration, but everything else has been pleasant.

review:
What was good or useful about Instagram is gradually whittled away until all social media platforms are the same, partitioning each individual into a separate box with a tailored stream of content designed to retain engagement and simulate an idea of community connection.
Updates are pushed asynchronously, which means that none of your friends have that new bad feature you just got, so they donâ€™t understand what youâ€™re complaining about, until one day you all do and itâ€™s just how it works now.
Iâ€™ve noticed the app withholds the dopamine hit from seeing the red dot that indicates ppl have liked your posts until youâ€™ve checked the app a couple times that day already; if you check it earlier, the likes are there, but really, that validation is just another tool in the quest to retain as much of your attention as possible.
Even beyond theses criticisms, for an image-centric platform, Instagram stores very low quality jpeg images, with some kind of automatic sharpen/contrast filter that makes non-photographic images look particularly bad.
Think critically about how you engage with this app, and pay attention to how the incremental changes make you feel. When you add them together, do you like where this platform is going?

review: I have always been the hugest Instagram fan, a photo sharing app turned viral and became an essential for our generation! For years Instagram was updated but the core values and aspects of the app remained the same. Now we are forced to look at an interface that is confusing and unpleasant for the eye. The addition of stories was nice, the addition of reels was unnecessary but we lived with it. Now it is changing how our own feeds are presented and the addition of a shopping focused update. Myself along with other millions of users downloaded this app to socialise and share moments in our lives. Not shopping. The notifications and posting tabs have now been moved to an insignificant location, in their place is the video and shopping tabs. The core focus of Instagram has been lost, we are all more than happy to view ads to maintain a free application and cover costs but this is taking it too far. Instagram for many young people is the first early glimpse of social media, now they are instantly attacked with shopping items instead of the same simple and enjoyable experience shared by many in recent years. Sadly this is goodbye to our beloved Instagram.

review: It has come to my attention that when someone posts something, they can be 'reposted'. These users put work and effort into their whatever-it-was and having someone claim it as their own without the work can sting. Most people (often fans of the artist) will repost with credit to the creator, but there are those who don't. Maybe if Instagram sent a notification every time one of your posts were reposted; art thieves wouldn't be much of a problem as the creator can check if they were credited and if they weren't, they can simply report the 'thief' for plagiarism. It might be useful. Oh and yes, I am aware to all those reading this that the Instagram creators probably don't read or take into consideration the reviews of their app. If so, then may this be a helpful warning to whoever is reading it about thieves.

review: Instagram is a good app to take and share photos, however, this allows you to share your location to strangers, which creates a safety issue as it is dangerous for some people to know your location. Your profile and all your photos are all accessible to everyone on instagram, but this can be solved by changing your account to private. Messaging is also a feature on instagram, and you could be a victim of cyber bullying, which is harmful for many people. You can block these people if you ever feel uncomfortable. However, a big issue is that there is a lot of inappropriate or graphic content, and as many children use the app regularly, they could be exposed to this type of content. Overall, instagram should be used in a limited way and you should be careful how you interact and what you are viewing.

review:
Dear Instagram Support Team,

I am writing to express my frustration and disappointment regarding the issues I have been experiencing with uploading photos on Instagram. I have been a loyal user of Instagram for many years, and I have never had any problems uploading photos until recently.

I have been attempting to upload photos to my Instagram account for the past few days, but the photos have not been uploading successfully. I have tried to upload the photos multiple times, but each time I get an error message stating that the upload was unsuccessful.

Sincerely,

review:
The recent update is spoiling my enjoyment of beautiful images and stories on Instagram. 

Before, you could enjoy the images in all their glory, most of them carefully photographed and edited to look good just as they are. Then you could go on to read the text underneath, clearly readable on a white background.

Now, every image looks duller with the annoying shading at the bottom. You canâ€™t see the image in itâ€™s entirety when the caption is superimposed over the bottom section of the photo. You also canâ€™t see the text in itâ€™s entirety as you have to carefully scroll through it on top of the picture, a couple of lines at a time. Itâ€™s also now harder to swipe through multiple images in one post.

This unnecessary update will have two effects on the Instagram community. Photographers will now have to think about how to get around this, instead of simply posting images in their own right. What was once an easy way to share just got a whole lot more work! Secondly, the update restricts written communication. I like to read usersâ€™ longer captions, where they tell a story. Sometimes I like to write longer captions too. I think weâ€™ll see this depth of communication drop off. 

Have the app developers even considered how difficult the text is to read for people with dyslexia or vision issues in itâ€™s current format?
title: Beautiful images and stories now ruined by Instagram

Today I had to add Rule 34 to my list of sensitive words and phrases to block out. The trigger to this was an animated/anime video of a young female child allude to sexual acts with an older male, the caption with the hashtag rule 34.
Not only is this type of content not meant to be on Instagram but it is disgusting and unethical.

I did not dare to look at the comments as I was afraid my worse fears were true, this Instagram content is harbouring harmful content to an extensively large audience from older viewers to children. Comment sections become grounds for sharing names to the source material.

These pornographic â€˜cartoonsâ€™ are often cropped, shortened, edited and muted with music to avoid repercussions and being reported.

As a parent, this change gives me really confident faith that my little girl won't grow up in such a superficial and heavily narcissistic world. I do know that the user is able to see the likes and you can press (where the likes are) to see who has liked the photo but no longer shall that number be one of the main reasons of motivation to post a photo to seek validation from strangers and peers and be such a toxic part of social media presence. 

So, for the small change I thank you Instagram Australia, the impact you have made is extreme and can only hope this helps the huge epidemic of suffering mental health throughout the generation of social media users. 

One proud Aussie :)

title: â€œAction blockedâ€

review:
Despite what appears to be a minor initial wave of criticism, the concept of removing likes is a well-considered one.

It upsets me that commenters below have shared sentiments to the effect of: â€œI miss the popularity contestâ€ and â€œwhatâ€™s the point of posting anymore.â€ 

Social media and more generally, communication, should ideally be valued by what is being said, rather than the individual who is saying it. It is telling (and perhaps alarming) that some feel there is no purpose to sharing the things we enjoy without a likes system. This post is not to scrutinise those who appreciate validation and positive feedback, which is something we are all guilty of, in part. To those who do find this essential, why is the fact that you can view how many likes your own post received insufficient? Is there some conceited pleasure to derive from surpassing others in this way?

I hope this update encourages us all to share more of what we love, free of fear, free of judgment and free of vanity.

review:
It is disappointing to learn that Instagram's parent company, Meta, is reportedly lobbying the US government to ban TikTok and restrict free speech, which goes against the fundamental values of the First Amendment. Such actions are not only concerning but also highlight the potential misuse of power by large tech corporations.

In light of these reports, it is difficult to overlook the unethical and hypocritical behavior of Instagram's ownership. While Instagram claims to support the values of free expression and creativity, its parent company's actions contradict those claims.

Furthermore, Instagram's user experience has been plagued by a barrage of targeted advertisements, algorithmic biases, and fake accounts, making it difficult for users to trust the platform. The constant pressure to present a "perfect" life through curated photos and videos can also take a toll on users' mental health.

Overall, it is disheartening to see a once-popular social media platform like Instagram being associated with such negative actions and behaviors. As consumers, we must hold these companies accountable for their actions and demand transparency and ethical practices.

The Israeli governmentâ€˜s Cyber Unit has effectively silenced thousands of voices by making requests with Facebook to delete anything that isnâ€™t in their favour. 

The head of Instagram, Adam Mosseri himself said in an interview, â€œWe've realized that we have a lot of responsibility to understand how our platform is used and to address any abuses whenever possible.â€
